. The sample code you're showing here returns a random size, and thus a different size every time the `prefferedSizeForItemAtIndexPath` method is called. The `prefferedSizeForItemAtIndexPath` is called multiple times throughout the layout process and expects a consistent size to be returned for each index path.

If you want to test with random sizes you should store them in an array and implement the delegate method like this

``` objective-c
return [[self.sizes objectAtIndex:indexPath.item] CGSizeValue];
```

Also make sure to set the contentMode on the cell's image view to aspect fill in this case.
. I've replicated your example with this code and it works perfectly:

```
- (id)initWithCoder:(NSCoder *)aDecoder
{
    self = [super initWithCoder:aDecoder];
    if (self) {

        _sizes = [NSMutableArray array];

        NSMutableArray *images = [[NSMutableArray alloc] init];
        for (int i = 1; i <= NUMBER_OF_IMAGES; i++) {
            NSString *imageName = [NSString stringWithFormat:@"photo-%02d.jpg", i];
            UIImage *image = [UIImage imageNamed:imageName];
            [images addObject:image];

            CGSize size = [image size];
            size.width += arc4random()%2000;
            size.height += arc4random()%2000;
            [_sizes addObject:[NSValue valueWithCGSize:size]];
        }
        _images = [images copy];
    }

    return self;
}

#pragma mark - UICollectionViewFlowLayoutDelegate

- (CGSize)collectionView:(UICollectionView *)collectionView layout:(NHBalancedFlowLayout *)collectionViewLayout preferredSizeForItemAtIndexPath:(NSIndexPath *)indexPath
{
    return [[self.sizes objectAtIndex:indexPath.item] CGSizeValue];
}
```

fingerco:
I'm not sure why it looks like it deleted things. It should be the exact same code just refactored in these ways:

NSArrays are initialized with a capacity (known from the variables used to iterate in the for loops). This prevents the arrays from having to reallocate memory as objects are added to them.

Instead of an NSDictionary which is then sorted to find the minimum, a running minimum is created. This speeds everything up because allocating a dictionary and adding to it takes up a lot of time relative to changing an NSInteger.

You may want to make sure that this is a complete refactor but my tests with the latest release lowered the time to process from 2 seconds to around 2/5ths of a second.
. On further inspection it looks like it removed that optimization. I'll integrate it and modify this request.
. It would seem that this performance issue was due to me using an outdated version of the library (the homepage suggests an outdated version) and this was a fix for that. Keep up the good work!
